awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to fabricate and study magnetic tunnel junctions with an active multiferroic or ferroelectric barrier - termed magneto-electric tunnel junctions. Traditional magnetic tunnel junctions represent a class of device that utilizes the electronic spin for its performance. The proposed magneto-electric tunnel junctions are based on theoretical predictions that have identified asymmetry as a fundamental criterion for obtaining multi-functional devices. These devices are expected to exhibit simultaneous magneto-resistance and electro-resistance effects, coupled with subtle electronic transport effects. A comprehensive research program is planned which addresses issues related to the following components: sample fabrication, structural characterization, nanoscale magneto-electric properties, and device characterization. The basic focus of the proposed program will be on the investigation of magneto-electric transport properties of magneto-electric tunnel junctions with ultra-thin ferroelectric and multiferroic barriers and their composites. 

The intellectual merit of the research lies in the investigation of novel heterostructures utilizing fundamental insight into electronic properties coupled with innovative fabrication and characterization methods that have the potential for realizing a new class of multiple-state resistance devices. State-of-the-art pulsed laser deposition techniques shall be used with unit-cell control to fabricate prototype devices. Device characteristics shall be investigated both at the nanoscale and global level. Nanoscale characterization would involve current-voltage characteristics of bilayer structures using conducting atomic force microscopy. Local ferroelectric switching properties of ultra-thin films shall be studied using piezoresponse force microscopy. Advanced scanning probe characterization investigating nanoscale ferroelectricity and tunneling properties shall be performed at the Center for Nanoscale Material Sciences at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. 

The Broader Impacts includes a multidisciplinary effort that will make significant contributions to scientific knowledge, education outreach and infrastructure. The scientific outcomes of the project are expected to include both advances in the fabrication of a new class of tunnel junction structures and fundamental understanding of their materials and physical characteristics. Device studies will provide a firm foundation for realizing multifunctional devices and, if successful, would have an extraordinary impact and open the door for a plethora of applications. The program will provide support for graduate and undergraduate students, including underrepresented minorities, and contribute to their broad interdisciplinary training. Project personnel will collaborate with local schools to facilitate participation by high school students in research.

por.por_cntn:
Magnetic tunnel junctions (MTJ) represent a class of device that actively utilizes electron spin for its performance. The ferromagnet-insulator-ferromagnet sandwich of an MTJ exploits all its primary functionality from the electrodes with the insulating barrier traditionally playing a passive role. A potentially powerful technique for device application in oxide materials is the magneto-electric (ME) effect. It is defined as the variation in the dielectric polarization under an applied magnetic field, or the magnetization under an external electric field. Most of the known single phase, bulk multiferroic materials studied thus far suffer from: (i) poor ME coupling, (ii) having a magnetic transition  temperature far below room temperature, and (iii) thin film fabrication of the single phase multiferroic material is difficult. Therefore, current work on ME effect have broadened beyond single-phase materials to include composite ferromagnetic/ferroelectric bilayers. This effect is the basis for a wide range of applications, including electrically tunable nonvolatile memory devices, ultra-sensitive magnetic field and position sensors, electrically controlled magnetic microwave devices, and magnetically-controlled piezoelectric devices. Moreover, composite ferromagnetic/ferroelectric tunnel junction devices offer the possibility of multiple-state memory as well as novel logic devices.

The goal of this project was to fabricate and study MTJs with an active multiferroic or ferroelectric barrier - which we name magneto-electric tunnel junctions (METJs). These devices are expected to show simultaneous magneto-resistance and electro-resistance effects, coupled with subtle electronic transport effects. The primary objectives were to gain a fundamental understanding of prototypical ferromagnetic-ferroelectric interfaces and explore their utility for a new class of devices. The focus of the project was on the investigation of magneto-electric transport properties of METJs with ultra-thin ferroelectric BaTiO3 and BiFeO3 barriers and their composites. In another aspect of the project we investigated new active materials for use as insulating barrier layer in MTJs. Our focus was on SrSnO3, as theoretical calculations predict a spin filtering effect in this material similar to magnesium oxide-based tunnel junctions State-of-the-art pulsed laser deposition techniques were used with unit-cell control to fabricate prototype devices. We demonstrated that it is indeed possible to grow ultrathin ferroelectric layers of a few unit cell thicknesses as the active tunneling barrier. Device characteristics were investigated both at the nanoscale and global level. Nanoscale characterization involved current-voltage characteristics of the ferromagnetic/ferroelectric bilayer structures using conducting atomic force microscopy. Local ferroelectric switching properties of ultra-thin films were studied using piezoresponse force microscopy. Magneto-transport characterization were performed on METJs devices with different combination of electrodes. Advanced scanning probe characterization investigating nanoscale ferroelectricity and tunneling properties were performed at the Center for Nanoscale Material Sciences (CNMS) at the Oak-Ridge National Laboratory.

       The project resulted in 14 journal publications, six invited talks and several contributed presentations. Two REU students and one High School student worked on the project during the period 2012 - 2014.
